heisig_chinese_memo: Behold Mr. T (of "A-Team" fame)! He is a very versatile character since he's both the big, tough guy and the â€œmoralisticâ€ person, telling kids not â€œto do drugs or alcoholâ€. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line â€œI pity da foo!â€ * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a â€œTâ€.
heisig_story: The character for enter (Frame 842) showed someone walking inwards (in terms of the direction of writing), the one for person, shown here, represents someone walking outwards.
koohiiStory1: Behold Mister T (of "A-Team" fame)! I chose Mr.T because heÂ´s sure to make amusing stories. He is a very versatile character since heÂ´s both the big, tough guy and the â€œmoralisticâ€ person, telling kids not â€œto do drugs or alcoholâ€. He is easy to imagine, the heavy gold chains are probably the most prominent feature of the character. And last but not least you can always pepper your story with the famous line â€œI pity da foo!â€ * Fittingly, on the left side of the kanji, it looks like a â€œTâ€.
koohiiStory2: [I appreciate some peopleÂ´s occasional habit of using P for person in shared stories. That makes it easier to substitute Mr. T, Captain Picard, or whomever else a student is using as person.].

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant person because it's a person walking from the side with their arms down? Well this is a person too!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Only one person at Nintendo (ã«ã‚“) complained about the new Jeans (ã˜ã‚“) policy, and that person was you.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine how angry you were about the policy. You'll have to come up with something to be angry about yourself (pick something that would actually make you angry, like maybe you're only allowed to wear cut off short-shorts jeans at Nintendo now), but if you pick something good, you'll definitely remember the two readings for this. Just remember you're working at Nintendo, and the policy has to be something about jeans. Then, imagine yourself as the only person complaining and everyone else in their dumb jeans (or lack-thereof) shaking their head at you because you're being a fool.

origin_of_ch_char_book: (ä¸€, yi, One) influenced its philosophical meaning to establish (å¤©, tian=tâ€™ien, heaven). This character is a combination of â€œa big manâ€ (å¤§, da, big) and the one and only and higher (ä¸€, yi, one). In other words, it expresses something higher than the highest person. The common person or man is expressed as bending his waist like this: (äºº, ren, human). When expressed as (å¤§, da, big), it means someone more powerful than a common man. Therefore, (å¤©, tian=tâ€™ien, heaven) means someone higher than the big man, the one and only being, that is the God who lives in Heaven. Therefore, this letter is currently being used as a meaning for Heaven, Day, or God.,There were three subjects that ancient East Asians considered to be the most important things in the universe. The principles are: Heaven, the Earth, and People. Heaven (å¤©, tian=tâ€™ien, heaven) means the most supreme God, the Earth (åœ°, di, earth) means mother earth where all living things are grown, and the People (äºº, ren, human) means the most important living being between heaven and mother earth.,The monument features the three supreme existences of the Universe: Heaven (å¤©), Earth(åœ°), and Human (äºº)â€” and the five basic elements of the universe: water(æ°´), fire(ç«), iron (é‡‘), wood(æœ¨), soil(åœŸ) (14th-19th century) ,(ä», ren, love) reflects such a philosophy. This character has two lines: , and has a human ( äºº, ren, human). These symbols mean all three elements, Heaven, Earth, and People. ä» (ren, love) does not only imply three elements, but also means â€œsincere loveâ€ for them. Confucius (552â€“479 BC) emphasized ä» (ren, love), the sincere love of Heaven, Earth and Human as the most ideal virtue for a wise man to have.,The coronation ceremony of Prince. The officials at the royal court were seated according to their status. The ceremonial practices were conducted in accordance with 13 procedures. Early 19th century in Korea. < National Palace Museum of Korea > Vassals in East Asia had to wear clothes in different colors depending on their status. Even when the memorial service was held at the royal palace, they had to be placed in a designated location. (ä½, wei, position; location) There is a man on the left side bending his waist (äºº, ren, human, people), and a well-dressed nobleman standing on the right side (ç«‹, li, stand). When the ceremonies were held in the royal court, the officials stood in position according to their status.,Part 2. äºº (Ren) Human,(äºº,ren, human) implies a profile of a person with his back bent, expressing the humility.,A nobleman wearing a topknot with a rod-like hairpin. Etching by Elizabeth Keith (1887~1956). Elaborate head-dress and an old man who is wearing it; the traditional hat old men usually wore. (14th-19th century) A child is depicted as (å…’, å„¿, er=erh, child). (äºº, ren, human) means people, then what does mean? Some say it means a child crying to the sky and some say that the bones of the head are not formed yet (as in a boyâ€™s head).,How did the Chinese refer to people who have passed away, the ancestors, in other words? They drew it like this: (å…ˆ, xian=hsien, earlier, elder generation). The top part (æ­¢, zhi=chih, stop) is the footprint going forth over a base line , and the bottom part (äºº, ren, human) means a person. That is, someone following the footsteps of the person who went before him/her.,(è–, åœ£, sheng, holy, sage) reflects the ancient Chinese thoughts about the holy person (sage). This symbol is composed of a person whose position is low (äºº, ren, human) and on the top an ear (è€³, er, ear), and a mouth (å£, kou, mouse) next to them. It shows someone listening to what others are saying. In his book â€œChun Qiuâ€, Confucius emphasizes how important it is to listen well to others, especially the heavenly God. This is why Confucius who listened attentively is regarded as â€œHoly Manâ€ or â€œSageâ€. Confucius said that â€œAt age sixty, I heard and followed (the words from the Heavens).â€ In other words, he is confessing that it took him sixty years to hear Heavenâ€™s command.,The first born son had a privilege as the inheritor of the parentsâ€™ family fortune. In return, the oldest son was responsible for the ceremonies of ancestors and parents. With such privilege, the eldest son had power over his younger siblings. Therefore, the eldest son often ordered his younger siblings around. (å…„, xiong=hsiung, elder brother) describes elder brother, which combines a (å£, kou, mouse) and a person (äºº, ren, human). Together, they symbolize â€œa person who speaks or gives ordersâ€. If the spirit tablet or altar (ç¤º, shi=shih, show) is added to the left , (ç¥, zhu, wish), it means the eldest brother who represents the group praying or calling a blessing from God. Then, how can the younger brother be depicted? The creator(s) of Hanzi thought about the sequence of brothers. The character (å¼Ÿ, di, younger brother) shows a spear in the middle (æˆˆ), and a rope winding the spear (). The reason for winding the spear is to prevent slippage and to make sure the spear will not break. This character came to mean â€œyounger brotherâ€ because of the meaning of winding order, or sequence. When you wind a rope around the spear, you have to do it in an orderly way. Therefore, it symbolizes the order in the ages of the siblings.,In ancient East Asia, women often carried their children on their backs. The baby feels protected and attached to the mother in this way (ä¿, bao, protect). This symbol combines a human (äºº, ren, human) with a child on the right (å­, zi=tzu, child) and two points which indicate a pair of hands holding the child. It shows a human carrying a child on his/her back. Now the word has come to mean to â€œprotectâ€. On the other hand, (æ£„, å¼ƒ, qi=châ€™i, abandon) shows a different scene. A child (å­, zi=tzu, child), just born with blood on the skin, is on top of a straw basket (å…¶, qi=châ€™i, that) and two hands are holding them from below. What is going on? Many people had to abandon their babies due to illness or famine when food was scarce. This character describes such a sad situation. Someone is throwing his/her baby in the basket.,(çœ‹, kan, see; look at) The upside is the hand with 5 fingers (æ‰‹, shou, hand) shading the eye (ç›®, mu, eye). It looks like someone spreads a palm to block the sun and looks around. (è¦‹, è§, jian=chien, see; meet with) consists of an eye and a kneeling person (äºº, ren, human), depicting a subject sees up at the king or a senior, expressing his opinion.,A man sitting cross-legged (1915) After walking and running, one would feel tired and thirsty and want to rest under the cool shade of a tree. (ä¼‘, xiu=hsiu, rest) is the description of a person (äºº, ren, human) resting under a tree (æœ¨, mu, tree).,The Yellow River that flows through China is one of the longest rivers in the world. The river is so long that the ancient Chinese probably thought that it was endless. Therefore, a long riverâ€™s endless flow came to mean â€œforeverâ€. (æ°¸, yong, forever) was created to mean such thoughts. The character shows a person (äºº, ren, human), a road (è¡Œ, xing=hsing, line), and a flow of water . It signifies a man swimming in the river: (æ³³, yong, swim) or walking next to a river. He would think the river is so long, and the flow of water is endless.,Stone tools in shape of shovels (Neolithic Age) The symbol for boundary is this: (ç•Œ, jie, boundary). The upper part of the symbol is a field (ç”°, tian=tâ€™ien, field) and the left shows a person (äºº, ren, human) between the two things (ä»‹, jie, be situated between). He is now deciding the exact borders of the fields.
humanum_full_description_en:
" Human " refers to human beings, "Shuowen": "Human, the most expensive nature of heaven and earth. This text is like the shape of a shin. Mortals belong to people." Warring States characters may add one to people. The dots are decorations, and the dots often extend into a horizontal line, which is corrupted into a " thousand " shape, so " person " and " thousand " are the differentiation of the word. See " thousands ".

Oracle is used as the original meaning, "Collection" 22626: "cut ten people", which means slashing ten people. "Compilation" 20328: "Yu Yiren" is the self-proclaimed King Yin. Also known as " Yi ", Fang's country name, "Ying" 2524: "Wang Zheng (Zheng) Renfang". "Ren Fang" means "Yi Fang", referring to Dong Yi.

Bronze inscriptions are used as the original meaning, Yi Hou Sui: "General", that is, common people. Huanzi Meng Jianghu: "People", Qi Houping: "Minren". "Zhou Li. Land official. Big Situ": "The map of the land where the nation was built and the number of its people." "Zuo Zhuan. "The Nine Years of Xianggong": "His scholar competed in teaching, and his subordinate manpower was in agriculture." This character is a combination of â€œa big manâ€ (å¤§, da, big) and the one and only and higher (ä¸€, yi, one). In other words, it expresses something higher than the highest person. Radicals: äºº  (person)
Meaning Mnemonic
Remember how the radical version of this kanji meant person because it's a person walking from the side with their arms down? Well this is a person too!
Know the radicals, and you shall know the kanji.
Reading Mnemonic
Only one person at Nintendo (ã«ã‚“) complained about the new Jeans (ã˜ã‚“) policy, and that person was you.
Imagine how angry you were about the policy.
